channel.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
channel.description:
Hey. I'm trying to make it so that a variable wont be for all players, but just for that one player.
Like, let's say when a player clicks on a tree, the clickTree handler would go something like [code]clickTree = 1;[/code]
Then when he clicks it again it would go to [b]Two.[/b] Then when a [b][i]different[/i][/b] player clicks on the tree, it wont start from 0 for its own player's variable, but instead it will continue on with the main (let's say server-wide) variable and would go to 3.
How do I make it so each player has there own seperate variable, even if the variable is the same (like clickTree)? I know client.java has this, but how would I make this work in a handler? I've tried connecting the variable from the handler to the client using static variables like client.clickTree but that didn't work either. Does anybody have an idea on how this would work?

Lol @ what Fr33Sc4p3 said.

So does anybody know why it is not working?

}[/code][/quote]

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Rofl @ You two.

Back on topic:
I did what you said, and what I’m really trying to do is make an anti-macro system and I set the clicktime in client.java by announcing that Player player client and making it player.clicktime = inStream.ReadDWord(); or whatever.

Then back in the handler I made it so every time player.clicktime equals the previous player.clicktime, it adds 1 to the sameclicklevel. When it reaches 7, it bans you. Then I tested it, banned myself, and when I went back online on a different account, it banned me instantly when I clicked on an object. Which means the player.sameclicklevel is the same for all players… meaning it didnt work. Any ideas on why is that?

EDIT: oh and my Player player client looks like this:

Player player = server.playerHandler.players[a];

A meaning the a variable which is set in client.java when I say server.blablaHandler.void(playerId). So a == playerId. So do I use playerId for it to be seperate? Is that right?

So like in your previous post where instead of a, it’s 4… 4 was meant to equal playerId right?

Read full topic

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Yep. Each player would have seperate numbers. You could use this code to list the clickTrees.

for(Player p : server.playerHandler.players) { if(p == null) continue; System.out.println(p.playerName + "::clickTree::" + p.clickTree); }

Read full topic
item.source: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Aftermath, post:7, topic:123567”]No, the class is with a capital letter.

player is an instance of the class player.

For example:

[code]Player player = server.playerHandler.players[4];
player.clickTree++;

if(player.clickTree == 1) doStuff();[/code]

If you want to use it directly, you have to make it public or protected instead of private. If you want to keep it private, you could add a getClickTree and setClickTree in client as well and make those public.[/quote]
Ok so if I went to client.java and added this line:

public int clickTree = 0;

Then went to my TreeHandler.java file and made this:

public void treeFTW(playerId)
{
Player p = server.playerHandler.players[playerId];
p.clickTree++;
p.sendMessage("You get some logs.");
}

Then went back to client.java and under the click tree case\switch I added this:

server.TreeHandler.treeFTW(playerId);

Everything would work fine and each player would have seperate numbers\data stored in the clickTree variable?

Read full topic
item.source: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

No, the class is with a capital letter.

player is an instance of the class player.

For example:

[code]Player player = server.playerHandler.players[4];
player.clickTree++;

if(player.clickTree == 1) doStuff();[/code]

If you want to use it directly, you have to make it public or protected instead of private. If you want to keep it private, you could add a getClickTree and setClickTree in client as well and make those public.

Read full topic
item.source: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

So…

I could declare

private int clickTree = 0;

in client.java…

Then in the handler I can just do

if(player.clickTree == 1)

--OR--

player.clickTree++;

Without any problems?

But wouldn’t the player prefix announce it as a static variable from the player.java file?

Read full topic
item.source: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Still, even if you’re using a handler, the best thing to do is keep the actual variables in the client and manipulate them from the handler.

From the handler, you could do player.clickTree++;

You can’t have the clickTree in the handler. You can use the clickTree in the client from there, though.

Read full topic
item.source: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Aftermath, post:2, topic:123567”]Put a “private int clickTree = 0” in client.java.

Wherever you want it to go up by 1, put “clickTree++;”[/quote]
Well… As I mentioned above I’m using a handler… so… can I do something like “private static int clickTree” and then in the handler use client.clickTree += 1; or something?

Read full topic

item.title: Seperate Player Variables in a Handler
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Put a “private int clickTree = 0” in client.java.

Wherever you want it to go up by 1, put “clickTree++;”
